716585f-a.title: Manhattan: Battery Place - Greenwich Street
716585f-a.text:
Battery Place, from Greenwich (left) to West (right)
Street's, as viewed northward from Battery Park prior to
the completion of the sea retaining wall. In the center
is Washington Street. To the left of same are the spires
of Trinity Church and St. Pauls Chapel, both on Broadway.
This is a reversed print.
About 1854
Gift of Urbrock Collection
716585f-a.folder: Battery Place & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY

731150f-c.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Civic Reception.
731150f-c.text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: Three views of
a civic reception at the Battery. Views 1 and 2 show the crowds
at the foot of West Street. No. 3 is photogranhed on Battery
Place at Greenwich Street.
About 1929
Views 1,2 and 3
731150f-c.folder: Battery Place and Greenwich Street, Manhattan, N.Y.

716582f-a.title: Manhattan: Battery Place - Greenwich Street
716582f-a.text:
A peanut vendor on the north side of Battery Park and showing also
cars on Battery Place with a station of the Sixth and Ninth Ave. Elevated
line at Greenwich Street. Vrominent structures is the Washington
Building which is No. 2 Battery Place.
October 7, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

716572f-a.title: Manhattan: Battery Place - Greenwich Street
716572f-a.text:
Battery Place, north side, from Greenwich, to and including West
Streets. Prominent building shown, is the whitehall Building. Piers ob-
served are Pier A, Nos. 1 and 2 Eudson River. The ship is the "Normandie" of
the Compagnie Generale Trans-Atlantique.
July 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
AEdG 2506
716572f-a.folder: Battery Place & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY

720167f.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Battery Place
720167f.text:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place, showing W.P.A. employees
removing the car tracks under the Sixth and Ninth Aves. elevated structure.
July 14, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.
720167f.folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

720170f-a.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Battery Place
720170f-a.text:

tNe 'Eg" atation at that point showing the Ninth Avenue "Eg"
tracks obscuring the street level. At the right are the Washington

E1ectric Bond and Share Building. The prominent structure shown
to the left and diamonally opposite the last named building is
a 35 storied structure bearing No. 21 Rector Street and is recent-
1y erected.

720171f-a.title: Manhattan: Greenwich Street - Battery Place
720171f-a.text:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place, as photographed
from the downtown "gg" platform. Shown are details o the 6th
and 9th Avenue 'El" station prior to demolition. This is the first
station out of South Ferry and is the oldest of any in the city.
Charles C. Harvey, the inventor, was permitted to erect an experi-
mental line from this point to 29th Street. Commencing service
in 1867 by wire rope locomotion, it failed in 1870 and was succeeded
by the N. Y. Elevated Railroad Company. This in turn became the
Manhattann Railway Company.
June 7, 1940
Views 1,2
P. L. Soerr
720171f-a.folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

716568f-a.title: Manhattan: Battery Place - Greenwich Street
716568f-a.text:
2 Battery Place, north side, from Greenwich Street (left) to Broadway
(right), showing the 12-story Washington Building that is better known as
No. 1 Broadway. On the right appears a view northward on Broadway, across
Bowling Green.
1921.
0ift of E.M. Jenks.

733388f-b.title: Transportation - Buses.
733388f-b.text:
Transportation--Buses: The green buses of the New York Omnibus
Corporation at Greenwich Street and Battery Place and at the South
Ferry 'El' terminal, Manhattan. Note the pillars of the Ninth Avenue
elevcted.
P. L. Sperr  View 11 December 24, 1940
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 2: April 28, 19441
